questions.text: Which type of synovial joint is seen in the picture?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Saddle joint The marked joint is between malleus & incus. Type of joint between malleus & incus – saddle joint. Type of joint between incus & stapes – ball & socket joint.

Highyeild:

The incus is the second of the ossicles, three bones in the middle ear which act to transmit sound. It is shaped like an anvil, and has a long and short crus extending from the body, which articulates with the malleus. The short crus attaches to the posterior ligament of the incus. The long crus articulates with the stirrup at the lenticular process.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Ball and socket Type of joint between incus & stapes – ball & socket joint. Option: C. Plane In a plane joint the mating surfaces of the bones are slightly curved and may be either ovoid or sellar. Only a small amount of gliding movement is found. Examples are the joints between the metacarpal bones of the hand and those between the cuneiform bones of the foot. Option: D. Pivot A pivot joint is a type of synovial joint that rotates. Two examples of pivot joints in your body are the pivot joint in your neck that allows your head to rotate and the pivot joints between the radius and ulna that rotate your forearm.

Extraedge:

Vibrations in the middle ear are received via the tympanic membrane. The malleus, resting on the membrane, conveys vibrations to the incus. This in turn conveys vibrations to the stapes.

questions.text: What is the role of the marked structure in the given image?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Memory The marked structure is the fornix of the brain. It is involved in the function of memory by connecting the hippocampus to the mammillary body. Coronal section of Brain showing body of Fornix

Highyeild:

The fornix is a C-shaped bundle of nerve fibers in the brain that acts as the major output tract of the hippocampus. The fornix also carries some afferent fibers to the hippocampus from structures in the diencephalon and basal forebrain. The fornix is part of the limbic system. While its exact function and importance in the physiology of the brain are still not entirely clear, it has been demonstrated in humans that surgical transection—the cutting of the fornix along its body—can cause memory loss. There is some debate over what type of memory is affected by this damage, but it has been found to most closely correlate with recall memory rather than recognition memory. This means that damage to the fornix can cause difficulty in recalling long-term information such as details of past events, but it has little effect on the ability to recognize objects or familiar situations.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - OPTION: A. Motor function The frontal lobes are the largest of the four lobes responsible for many different functions. These include motor skills such as voluntary movement, speech, intellectual and behavioral functions. The areas that produce movement in parts of the body are found in the primary motor cortex or precentral gyrus. OPTION: B. Reward - Punishment The mesolimbic system, also known as the reward system, is composed of brain structures that are responsible for mediating the physiological and cognitive processing of reward. OPTION: D. Judgment Frontal lobe of the brain is home to areas that manage thinking, emotions, personality, judgment, self-control, muscle control and movements, memory storage and more.

questions.text: The image given below shows the MRI of the knee. Identify the marked structure:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

PCL The given image is of MRI knee joint – sagittal view. Marked structure is the posterior cruciate ligament of the knee. Posterior cruciate ligament of the knee as seen in MRI of Knee joint

Highyeild:

The posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) works as a counterpart to the anterior cruciate ligament (ACL). It connects the posterior intercondylar area of the tibia to the medial condyle of the femur. This configuration allows the PCL to resist forces pushing the tibia posteriorly relative to the femur. The PCL and ACL are intracapsular ligaments because they lie deep within the knee joint. They are both isolated from the fluid-filled synovial cavity, with the synovial membrane wrapped around them. The PCL gets its name by attaching to the posterior portion of the tibia. The PCL, ACL, MCL, and LCL are the four main ligaments of the knee.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - OPTION: A. ACL OPTION: C. MCL OPTION: D. Synovial capsule The given image is of MRI knee joint – sagittal view. Marked structure is the posterior cruciate ligament of the knee, therefore Option A,C and D are incorrect answers.

Extraedge:

Muscles producing movements at the knee joint Movement Principal muscles Extension (from sitting on a chair to standing) Quadriceps femoris (four heads) Locking (standing in 'attention') Vastus medias Unlocking (standing 'at ease') Popliteus Flexion 1. Biceps femoris 2. Semitendinosus 3. Semimembranosus Medial rotation of flexed leg 1. Popliteus 2. Semimembranosus 3. Semitendinosus Lateral rotation of flexed leg Biceps femoris

questions.text: Which of the following is derived from the marked structure?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ribs The structure marked is the somite of the embryo. Among the given options, ribs are the one which develops from somite.

Highyeild:

Somites are segmental axial structures of vertebrate embryos that give rise to vertebral columns, ribs, skeletal muscles, and subcutaneous tissues.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Kidney Kidney develops from intermediate mesoderm. Option: C. Smooth muscles Smooth muscles develop from splanchnic mesoderm. Option: D. Diaphragm Diaphragm develops from septum transversum & pleuroperitoneal membrane.

Extraedge:

Number of Somites Correlated to Approximate Age in Days Approximate Age (d) Number of Somites 20 1-4 21 4-7 22 7-10 23 10-13 24 13-17 25 17-20 26 20-23 27 23-26 28 26-29 30 34-35

questions.text: A patient's right hip drops when he takes the right foot off the ground. Which of the following would not be involved in the patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Sciatic nerve The given description is of the Trendelenburg sign. It is seen in case of superior gluteal nerve palsy/lesion. As the sup. Gluteal nerve supplies the gluteus medius & minimus muscle; hence all these 3 structures will be involved.

Highyeild:

Trendelenburg’s sign Normally when the body weight is supported on one limb, the glutei of the supported side raise the opposite and unsupported side of the pelvis. However, if the abductor mechanism is defective, the unsupported side of the pelvis drops, and this is known as a positive Trendelenburg’s sign. The sign is positive in defects of power, i.e. paralysis of the glutei medius and minimus; defects of the fulcrum, i.e. congenital or pathological dislocation of the hip; and defects of the weight, i.e. ununited fracture of the neck of femur.

questions.text: The marked structure is connected to which thalamus nucleus?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Anterior nucleus of thalamus The marked structure is the fornix which connects the hippocampus to the mammillary body. It is connected to the anterior thalamic nuclei through the mammillary body by the mammillo-thalamic tract.

Highyeild:

Mammillothalamic tract (also called bundle of Vicq d'Azyr) Mammillothalamic tract is a prominent bundle of fibres which carry impulses from the mammillary body to the anterior nucleus of thalamus. It also includes some thalamo mammary fibres. Mammillothalamic tract is readily demonstrable by gross dissection. The efferents from anterior nucleus of thalamus are projected mainly to areas 23 and 24 of the cingulate gyrus but some fibres are also shunted to the tegmental nuclei of the midbrain through mammillo-tegmental tract .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Posterior nucleus of thalamus Option: C. Pulvinar nucleus Option: D. Ventro-postero lateral nucleus of thalamus The marked structure is the fornix which connects the hippocampus to the mammillary body. It is connected to the anterior thalamic nuclei through the mammillary body by the mammillo-thalamic tract, therefore Option B, C and D are incorrect answers.

Table:

#MANTRA The Papez circuit includes the following limbic structure

Solution:

Axilla Apocrine glands are a type of sweat glands that are present in axilla & perineal region & are responsible for the production of odour.

Highyeild:

The manner in which their secretions are poured out of the cells: Merocrine : In most exocrine glands secretions are thrown out of the cells by a process of exocytosis, the cell remaining intact, this manner of secretion is described as merocrine, e.g. goblet cell (sometimes also called eccrine or epicrine). Apocrine: In some glands the apical parts of the cells are shed off to discharge the secretion, this manner of secretion is described as apocrine. An example of apocrine secretion is seen in some atypical sweat glands and in mammary glands. Holocrine: In some glands, the entire cell disintegrates while discharging its secretion. This manner of discharging secretion is described as holocrine, and is seen typically in sebaceous glands.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Scalp Option: C. Face Option: D. Palms & sole Apocrine glands are a type of sweat glands that are present in the axilla & perineal region & are responsible for the production of odour, therefore option B, C and D are incorrect options.

Extraedge:

Comparison between serous and mucous acini Serous acini Mucous acini Triangular cells with rounded nucleus at the base. Cell boundaries are indistinct Tall cells with flat nucleus at the base. Cell boundaries are distinct Contain zymogen granules Contain mucoid material Darkly stained with H & E (because of the presence of zymogen granules, the color varies from pink to dark purple) Lightly stained and appear empty with H & E– Thin watery secretion Thick mucoid secretion Example: Parotid gland Example: Sublingual gland

questions.text: The marked structure is supplied by which of the following arteries?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Posterior Inferior cerebellar artery The marked structure is supplied by the posterior inferior cerebellar artery, which is a branch of vertebral artery. Posterior inferior cerebellar artery: This supplies the posterolateral part of the medulla.

Highyeild:

The posterior inferior cerebellar artery supplies the medulla oblongata, dorsal to the olivary nucleus and lateral to the hypoglossal nucleus. The artery also supplies the inferior surface of the cerebellum and sends a branch to supply the choroid plexus of the fourth ventricle.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - OPTION: A.Vertebral artery The vertebral arteries in the neck supply blood to the brain and spine. OPTION: B.Superior cerebellar artery The superior cerebellar artery (SCA) arises from the distal basilar artery, just below the posterior cerebral artery (PCA) and typically supplies: whole superior surface of the cerebellar hemispheres down to the great horizontal fissure superior vermis dentate nucleus most of the cerebellar white matter parts of the midbrain superior cerebellar peduncle middle cerebellar peduncle OPTION: D. Basilar artery The basilar artery (BA) serves as the main conduit for blood flow through the posterior circulation. It directly supplies the brainstem and cerebellum and provides distal blood flow to the thalami and medial temporal and parietal lobes.

Extraedge:

Lateral Medullary/Wallenberg Syndrome: Occurs due to blockage of posterior inferior cerebellar artery. It supplies areas behind the inferior olivary nucleus. Features are: Ipsilateral paralysis of most muscles of soft palate, pharynx and larynx due to injury to nucleus ambiguus which gives fibres to IX, X and XI cranial nerves. Loss of pain and temperature on the same side of the face due to involvement of the spinal nucleus and spinal tract of the trigeminal nerve. Loss of pain and temperature on the opposite side of the body due to involvement of lateral spinothalamic tract. Giddiness due to involvement of vestibular nuclei. Damage to inferior cerebellar peduncle, spino- cerebellar tracts and part of cerebellum results in loss of equilibrium, i.e. ataxia of limbs on the same side. The sympathetic fibres descend from the hypothalamus to cells in the lateral horn of the spinal cord. As these fibers descend in the lateral part of medulla (which is damaged), there is Horner’s syndrome, comprising ptosis, enophthalmos, miosis and anhydrosis. Lesions of medulla oblongata: (1) Medial medullary syndrome; (2) Lateral medullary syndrome

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect about the anomaly shown below?

options.label: A
options.text: It occurs due to the persistence of prechordal plate

options.label: B
options.text: It occur due to the defective migration of primordial cells to the genital ridge

options.label: C
options.text: It contains skin, cartilage and bone

options.label: D
options.text: It can be both benign and malignant tumor of coccyx

questions.correct_answer: A. It occurs due to the persistence of prechordal plate
questions.explanation:
Solution:

It occurs due to the persistence of prechordal plate The given image is of a sacrococcygeal teratoma. Sacrococcygeal teratoma ( SCT ) is a type of tumor known as a teratoma that develops at the base of the coccyx (tailbone) and is thought to be primarily derived from remnants of the primitive streak. Sacrococcygeal teratomas are benign 75% of the time, malignant 12% of the time, and the remainder are considered "immature teratomas" that share benign and malignant features. Benign sacrococcygeal teratomas are more likely to develop in younger children who are less than 5 months old, and older children are more likely to develop malignant sacrococcygeal teratomas.

Highyeild:

Remnants of the primitive streak persist in the sacrococcygeal region. These clusters of pluripotent cells proliferate and form tumors, known as sacrococcygeal teratomas, which commonly contain tissues derived from all three germ layers . This is the most common tumor in newborns, occurring with a frequency of 1 in 37,000. Teratomas may also arise from primordial germ cells that fail to migrate to the gonadal ridge.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. It occur due to the defective migration of primordial cells to the genital ridge Option: C. It contains skin, cartilage and bone Option: D. It is a benign tumor of coccyx Option B, C and D are correct statements about sacrococcygeal teratoma.

Solution:

Respiratory bronchiole The marked structure is the respiratory bronchiole which is ending into the alveolar sac.

Highyeild:

Intrapulmonary Passages On entering the lung the prin­cipal bronchus divides into secondary, or lobar bronchi (one for each lobe). Each lobar bronchus divides into tertiary, or segmental bronchi (one for each segment of the lobe). The segmental bronchi divides into smaller and smaller bronchi, which ultimately end in bronchioles. The lung substance is divided into numerous lobules each of which receives a lobular bronchiole. The lobular bronchiole gives off a number of terminal bronchioles. As indicated by their name the terminal bronchioles represent the most distal parts of the conducting passage. Each terminal bronchiole ends by dividing into respiratory bronchioles. These are so called because they are partly respiratory in function as some air sacs arise from them. Each respiratory bronchiole ends by dividing into a few alveolar ducts. Each alveolar duct ends in a passage, the atrium, which leads into a number of rounded alveolar sacs. Each alveolar sac is studded with a number of air sacs or alveoli.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Intrapulmonary bronchus: On entering the lung the prin­cipal bronchus divides into secondary, or lobar bronchi (one for each lobe) Option: B. Terminal bronchiole: Each terminal bronchiole ends by dividing into respiratory bronchioles. Option: D. Alveolar sac: Each respiratory bronchiole ends by dividing into a few alveolar ducts. Each alveolar duct ends in a passage, the atrium, which leads into a number of rounded alveolar sacs. Each alveolar sac is studded with a number of air sacs or alveoli.

questions.text: The sulcus located deep to the marked structure is ?
questions.correct_answer: B. Stem of the lateral sulcus
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Stem of the lateral sulcus The marked structure in the image is the pterion. From the given options, Stem of lateral sulcus is the correct option which is present beneath the pterion. Pterion

Highyeild:

Pterion: The region in the anterior part of the temporal fossa where four bones (frontal, parietal, squamous temporal, and greater wing of the sphenoid) meet to form an H-shaped suture is called pterion. It is situated 4 cm above the midpoint of the zygomatic arch.

Extraedge:

The asterion is an anatomical landmark on the lateral aspect of the skull formed at the junction of the occipital bone, the temporal bone, and the parietal bone.

options.label: B
options.text: Both the adrenal glands are retroperitoneal

options.label: C
options.text: Both the glands are yellow in color

options.label: D

questions.correct_answer: A. The right adrenal gland is semilunar in shape
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The right adrenal gland is semilunar in shape The right adrenal gland is pyramidal in shape. Left adrenal gland is semilunar in shape. The suprarenal glands

Highyeild:

Comparison of right and left suprarenal glands Right suprarenal gland Left suprarenal gland Shape Pyramidal Semilunar Parts and relations Apex: Bare area of liver Base: Upper pole of right kidney Upper end: Close to spleen Lower end: Presents hilum, left vein emerges from here Anterior surface Inferior vena cava, bare area of liver Cardiac end of stomach, pancreas with splenic artery Posterior surface Right crus of diaphragm, right kidney Left crus of diaphragm, left kidney (Fig. 25.3g) Anterior border Presents hilum, right vein emerges - Medial border Coeliac ganglion Coeliac ganglion Lateral border Liver Stomach

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Both the adrenal glands are retroperitoneal Option: C. Both the glands are yellow in color Option: D. Left adrenal gland is in close proximity to tail of pancreas & spleen Option B,C and D are correct statements about adrenal glands.

questions.text: Match the following muscles with their respective action at the shoulder joint:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A-2, B-4, C-3, D-1 The pectoralis major's primary functions are flexion, adduction, and internal rotation of the humerus. The latissimus dorsi adduct, medially rotate, and extend the arm at the glenohumeral joint. The supraspinatus muscle performs abduction of the arm, and pulls the head of the humerus medially towards the glenoid cavity. It independently prevents the head of the humerus from slipping inferiorly. Infraspinatus laterally rotates the arm.

Highyeild:

The supraspinatus forms part of the rotator cuff and is one of its most frequently damaged components, whether from acute injury or gradual degeneration. Bad posture and age are leading risk factors, with a high prevalence of unsymptomatic partial and full tears, as well as symptomatic syndromes with chronic pain. Connected pathologies include acromial impingement, frozen shoulder, and poor sleep, especially on the side. Both ultrasound and MRI are now effective methods of diagnosis.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. A-3, B-4, C-1, D-2 Option: B. A-1, B-3, C-2, D-4 Option: D. A-2, B-1, C-3, D-4 Option: A, B and D are incorrectly matched.

questions.text: The fibers of the internal oblique muscle and transverse abdominus muscle contribute together to form which boundaries of the inguinal canal walls:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Roof Boundaries of the inguinal canal are Anterior wall – external oblique muscle Posterior wall – fascia transversalis Roof – internal oblique + transversus abdominis Floor – inguinal ligament.

Highyeild:

CONTENTS of Inguinal Canal In male: Spermatic cord and ilioinguinal nerve. In female: Round ligament of the uterus and ilioinguinal nerve.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Roof and anterior wall Option: C. Floor Option: D. Posterior wall Internal oblique and Transversus abdominis forms the roof of the inguinal canal so Option A, C and D are incorrect answers.

questions.text: Given below is an illustration of a transverse section of the heart. Identify the marked structure:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Subaortic curtain The subaortic curtain is part of the fibrous skeleton of the heart. It is a fibrous sheet that spans the gap between the fibrous arches supporting the right posterior and left posterior leaflets of the aortic valve. It passes inferiorly within the wall of the right atrium.

Highyeild:

This fibrous curtain allows for specific surgical techniques to enlarge the aortic root. The ends of the subaortic, or aorto-mitral, curtain thicken to form the right and left fibrous trigones, anchoring the aortic-mitral unit within the short axis of the left ventricular cone.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Posterior leaflet of mitral valve: The mitral valve consists of the anterior and posterior leaflets, also known as the aortic and mural leaflets, respectively. The posterior leaflet is the narrower of the two, and spans two-thirds of the area around the left atrioventricular junction within the inlet portion of the left ventricle. Option: C.Aortic valve leaflet: Between the left ventricle and the aorta is the aortic valve, one of the heart's four valves. These valves help the blood flow through the heart's four chambers and out to the body. The aortic valve normally has three small parts, called leaflets. Sometimes, two leaflets develop instead of three. Option: D. Anterior aortic sinus: An aortic sinus, also called the sinuses of Valsalva is one of the anatomic dilatations of the ascending aorta, which occurs just above the aortic valve. These widenings are between the wall of the aorta and each of the three cusps of the aortic valve.

questions.text: Which of the following muscles are supplied by the lateral Plantar nerve? Abductor hallucis Flexor digitorum accesorius Flexor hallucis brevis First lumbrical First interossei Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

2 and 5 The lateral plantar nerve is an important motor nerve in the foot as it innervates all the intrinsic muscles in the sole, except for the muscles supplied by the medial plantar nerve (abductor hallucis, flexor digitorum brevis, flexor hallucis brevis, and first lumbrical).

Highyeild:

The medial plantar nerve (MPN) is the larger of the two terminal divisions of the tibial nerve, which accompanies the medial plantar artery. From its origin under the laciniate ligament, it passes deep to the abductor hallucis muscle, and, appearing between this muscle and the flexor digitorum brev

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - OPTION: B. 3 and 4 OPTION: C. 1 and 3 OPTION: D. 2 and 4 The medial plantar nerve innervates : Abductor hallucis, flexor digitorum brevis, flexor hallucis brevis, and first lumbrical, therefore option B,C and D are incorrect answers.

questions.text: Which of the following is a tributary of the inferior vena cava?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Left inferior phrenic vein The left Inferior phrenic vein drains into the following: the IVC inferior to the diaphragm in 37%, the left suprarenal vein in 25%, the left renal vein in 15%, the left hepatic vein in 14%, and both the IVC and the left adrenal vein in 1% of the specimens. The Inferior Phrenic Veins drain the diaphragm and follow the course of the inferior phrenic arteries. The right ends in the inferior vena cava.

Highyeild:

Tributaries of IVC - Apart from the common iliac veins, there are 6 pairs of veins, 2 singular veins and a hepatic group of veins, which drain into the inferior cava directly. They include: Four pairs of lumbar veins The right gonadal vein A pair of renal veins The right suprarenal vein A pair of inferior phrenic veins A group of hepatic veins

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - OPTION: B. Left supra -renal vein: The right suprarenal vein drains into the inferior vena cava and the left suprarenal vein drains into the left renal vein or the left inferior phrenic vein. OPTION: C. Left gonadal vein: The right gonadal vein usually drains into the inferior vena cava (IVC) while the left gonadal vein drains into the left renal vein (RV). OPTION: D. Right ascending lumbar vein : The ascending lumbar veins unite with the corresponding subcostal veins to form the azygos vein on the right and hemiazygos vein on the left. Occasionally, the ascending lumbar veins might drain into the first lumbar veins.
